Back in April I outlined an idea for maintaining broad diversity
within a population which I consider to be a generalisation on novelty
search. I'm still working on that front in order to try and get some
expeimental results to back up (or refute) the idea. In the mean time
though while working on a test problem it occurred to me that there's
a very easy change we perhaps should all be making in our existing
NEAT code, and that is to select genomes from a larger proportion of
the population. Withn NEAT we tend to think of speciation with fitness
sharing as the principle mechanism for maintaining diversity, which it
does do. But if at each generation we keep, say, the top 20% of each
species (elitism) and also select from that same 20% then we're giving
up a futher source of diversity within each species. (20% is the
default in SharpNEAT but I think similar values are generally used in
most NEAT based work).

If we think about populations in the natural world then they have a
much lower turnover rate where some small proportion die and are
replaced each year. Of course if you pick a longer period of time the
turnover rate per unit of time is higher, but the point is that there
is a more continuous and slow 'turnover' in populations, and this
allows diverse set of genomes to create offspring over and over again
despite having relatively low fitness. It's a balance between faster
approach to local optima (and potnetially gettign stuck) and takign a
broader slower approach taking in a broader region of the search
space.

I still think there's additional merit in breaking the region down in
sub-regions and balancing the diversity evenly, hence I will be
pursuing that idea, but for now many of us can improve diversity in
our searches by tweaking some config settings. I tried this with a
deceptive task that required an ANN to both balance a pole but also to
swing it up from a position where the pole is pointing straight down.
It's quite tricky combining the fitness from these two seperate tasks
and increasing the elitism and selection proportions substantially
does seem to help in this instance (e.g. I tried 80%).

Colin.
